title: Paper accepted at GeoAI @ SigSpatial 2021!
text: We‚Äôll be presenting our tutorial on the workshop day, November 2nd. You can find our paper at the arxiv website and the conference proceedings. We hope to see you there! Update: hex2vec has been implemented in our Spatial Representations for Artificial Intelligence library - SRAI.

title: Paper accepted at ARIC @ SigSpatial 2021!
text:
We‚Äôll be presenting on the workshop day, November 2nd at 10:00 AM local time. You can find our paper at the arxiv website and the conference proceedings. We hope to see you there! Feel free to see the demo of our solution.
Update: transfer learning approaches have been implemented in our Spatial Representations for Artificial Intelligence library - SRAI.

title: Geospatial Machine Learning Tutorial at ML in PL 2023
text:
The tutorial, titled ‚ÄúIntroduction to Geospatial Machine Learning,‚Äù is scheduled for Sunday, 29th October, from 09:00 - 13:00. Participants will gain insights into the geospatial domain using Python libraries and learn the applications of open-source geospatial data. A significant portion will highlight the features of the srai (Spatial Representation for Artificial Intelligence) library developed by our team, along with other libraries like GeoPandas, Shapely, osmnx, and scikit-learn. We‚Äôre enthusiastic about providing hands-on learning, and as such, tutorial materials will be shared in the form of Jupyter notebooks.
Please check:

the conference‚Äôs main website
the tutorial materials - GitHub
the registration page

title: Our PhD scholarship proposal has been accepted for financing by the Unite! project!
text: The scholarship will be released jointly by the University of Lisbon and Wroc≈Çaw University of Science and Technology, by advisors: Bruno Martins (UL) and Piotr Szyma≈Ñski (Wroc≈ÇawTech). More information can be found on the university website.

title: SRAI Tutorial Accepted at EuroSciPy 2023!
text:
The conference takes place from Monday, August 14, to Friday, August 18, in Basel, Switzerland. We‚Äôll be presenting our tutorial on the first day, Monday, August 14 at 10:30 AM (Europe/Berlin). You can find more information on the conference‚Äôs main website and the schedule page. We hope to see you there!

Tutorial materials - GitHub
Poster - PDF

title: Piotr Szyma≈Ñski PhD
text:
He is an alumni of the Top 500 Innovators program at Stanford University, worked in several institutions over the years incl.¬†Hasso Plattner Institute in Potsdam, Josef Stefan Institute in Ljubljana, University of Notre Dame and University of Technology Sydney. He is the author of Scikit-multilearn - a popular python library for multi-label classification, and pqdm - a parallel processing wrapper for tqdm.
Apart from multi-label classification, Piotr published papers concerning urban data, traffic analysis and bridging the gap between ASR and NLP in spoken language understanding systems. In his free time he is an urban activist in Wroc≈Çaw - chairing the Society of Beautification of the City of Wroc≈Çaw, and a member of Wroc≈Çaw city district council of Broch√≥w.
Recently he became a member of the international group which models coronavirus spread: MOCOS, which publishes regular reports about the state of the pandemic in Poland and also analysis of related phenomena.

title: News
text:
Geospatial Machine Learning Tutorial at ML in PL 2023


Introduction to Geospatial Machine Learning


Members of Kraina AI will be presenting a comprehensive tutorial on geospatial machine learning at the ML in PL Conference 2023 in Warsaw, Poland.






Oct 29, 2023


1 min






  




Paper accepted for the UrbanAI @ SIGSPATIAL 2023!


Map Diffusion Text Promptable Map Generation Model


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that our submission to the UrbanAI workshop at SIGSPATIAL 2023 has been accepted! We‚Äôll be presenting a paper describing the first diffusion model for text-promptable map generation - Map Diffusion.






Oct 20, 2023


1 min






  




Paper accepted for the GeoAI @ SIGSPATIAL 2023!


SRAI: Towards Standardization of Geospatial AI


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that our submission to the GeoAI workshop at SIGSPATIAL 2023 has been accepted! We‚Äôll be presenting a paper describing our open-source library for geospatial data processing and represenation learning.






Oct 7, 2023


1 min






  




SRAI Tutorial Accepted at EuroSciPy 2023!


Introduction to Geospatial Machine Learning with SRAI


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that our submission to EuroSciPy 2023 has been accepted! We‚Äôll be presenting a tutorial on geospatial machine learning with SRAI and a poster about the SRAI project.






Jun 15, 2023


1 min






  




Our PhD scholarship proposal has been accepted for financing by the Unite! project!


Using Large Language Models in the Context of Understanding and Generating Geospatial Language and Data


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that the Unite! meta university project will be financing our proposal for a PhD position on the verge of NLP and geospatial data with a focus on large language models and content generation.






May 16, 2023


1 min

highway2vec: representing OpenStreetMap microregions with respect to their road network characteristics


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that our submission to GeoAI@SigSpatial 2022 has been accepted! We‚Äôll be presenting a paper on OpenStreetMap region representation learning with respect to their road network characteristics.






Oct 2, 2022


1 min






  




Paper accepted at ARIC @ SigSpatial 2021!


Transfer Learning Approach to Bicycle-sharing Systems‚Äô Station Location Planning Using OpenStreetMap Data


We‚Äôre delighted to announce that our submission to the 4th ACM SIGSPATIAL Workshop on Advances on Resilient and Intelligent Cities (ARIC) has been accepted! We‚Äôll be presenting a paper on effective geographic transfer learning using OpenStreetMap region features for bike station location predictions.

title: Kraina
text:
At Kraina Lab, we embark on pioneering studies, leveraging advanced technologies and analytical methodologies to unravel the intricate complexities of geospatial phenomena and mobility patterns. Our interdisciplinary approach empowers us to extract meaningful insights from vast datasets, revolutionizing the understanding of urban dynamics, transportation systems, and spatial interactions.
We are a part of the Department of AI at Wroc≈ÇawTech‚Äôs Faculty of Information and Communication Technology.

title: Kraina
text:
Our Key Areas of Focus:
üìç Geospatial Analysis: Employing state-of-the-art spatial data processing techniques, we discern spatial relationships and distribution patterns, uncovering crucial spatial trends.
üöó Mobility Insights: Through extensive data mining and modeling, we investigate the dynamics of human and vehicular mobility, optimizing transportation networks and fostering sustainable urban development.

üîì Open source: At Kraina we are actively improving the tooling around the geospatial domain. Take a glimpse into our projects:

Spatial Representations for Artificial Intelligence





Project Spatial Representations for Artificial Intelligence (srai) aims to provide simple and efficient solutions to geospatial problems that are accessible to everybody and reusable in various contexts where geospatial data can be used. It is a Python module integrating many geo-related algorithms in a single package with unified API.
See SRAI for more information.


Bicycle Sharing System - Station Location Recommendation





Based on data collected from 34 European cities, a method for automatically generating a heat map has been developed to support planners in developing the layout of bike sharing stations. The model was developed as part of a Master‚Äôs thesis and published at the ARIC workshop at SIGSPATIAL 2021. The website allows the user to view all generated results for different cities of the world for many of the available heat map models with the possibility to change the colour scheme and style of the map.
See the website for more information or visit the publication.


Map Diffusion - Text Promptable Map Generation





Map Diffusion is a novel text promptable map generation model, leveraging recent advancements in generative models. Promptable map generation has broad applications, democratizing access to geographic data, enhancing decision-making, improving communication, and enabling customization. Map Diffusion generates maps based on textual descriptions, allowing users to describe a region, and the model generates a corresponding map.
